sen.j: 持統天皇（じとうてんのう・大化元年（645年） - 大宝 (日本)2年12月22日 (旧暦)（703年1月13日））は、日本の第41代天皇。
sen.e: The Empress Jito (645 – January 17, 703) was the forty-first emperor (empress regnant) of Japan.
Empress Jito (645 – January 17, 703) was the forty-first imperial ruler (empress regnant) of Japan.
sen.cmt: You can't really call an empress an emperor so I have changed the latter to "imperial ruler".
sen.e: Empress Jito (645 – January 17, 703) was the forty-first imperial ruler (empress regnant) of Japan.
sen.cmt: 天皇なのでスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 女性天皇である（称制：朱鳥元年9月9日 (旧暦)（686年10月1日）、在位：持統天皇4年1月1日 (旧暦)（690年2月14日） - 持統天皇11年8月1日 (旧暦)（697年8月22日））。
sen.e: She started shosei (ruling without official accession to the Chrysanthemum Throne) on October 4, 686, and after enthronement, her regnancy continued from February 17, 690 to August 25, 697.
sen.cmt: 「女性天皇である」旨はここまでのempress, she という言葉で分かるので、特に訳していません。
sen.e: Her shosei (rule without having officially ascended to the Chrysanthemum Throne) began on October 4, 686, and following her enthronement, she ruled from February 17, 690 to August 25, 697.
Her shosei (rule without having officially ascended to the Chrysanthemum Throne) began on October 4, 686, and following her enthronement, she ruled from February 17, 690 to August 25, 697.

sen.j: 名は野讚良（うののさらら、またはうののささら）。
sen.e: Her name was Uno no Sarara or Uno no Sasara.
Her name was Uno no Sarara (her name could also be pronounced Uno no Sasara).
Her name was Uno no Sarara (also known as Uno no Sasara).
sen.cmt: 統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 和風諡号は2つあり、『続日本紀』の大宝3年（703年）12月17日の火葬の際の「大倭根子天之廣野日女尊」（おほやまとねこあめのひろのひめのみこと）と、『日本書紀』の養老4年（720年）に代々の天皇とともに諡された「高天原廣野姫天皇」（たかまのはらひろのひめのすめらみこと）がある。
sen.e: She has two Japanese-style posthumous names: one is 'Oyamatoneko ame no hironohime no mikoto,' which appears in "Shoku-Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) at the scene of her cremation on January 31, 704; the other is 'Takamanohara hiro no hime no sumeramikoto' referred to in "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) as the name given to her in 720 when other emperors also received that kind of names.

She has two Japanese-style posthumous names: one is 'Oyamatoneko ame no hironohime no mikoto,' which is used to refer to her in the description given in the "Shoku-Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) of her cremation on January 31, 704; the other is 'Takamanohara hiro no hime no sumeramikoto,' which is referred to in the "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) as the name given to her in 720, a time when other emperors also received that kind of name.

She had two Japanese-style posthumous names: One was 'Oyamatoneko Ame no Hironohime no Mikoto,' which was used to refer to her in the description given in the "Shoku-Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued) of her cremation on January 31, 704; the other is 'Takamanohara Hiro no Hime no Sumeramikoto,' which was referred to in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) as the name given to her in 720, a time when other emperors also received that kind of name.

sen.j: （なお『日本書紀』において「高天原」が記述されるのは冒頭の第4の一書とこの箇所のみである。）
sen.e: (The word 'Takamanohara' appears in "Nihon Shoki" only twice; one is this reference of the Empress Jito and the other appears in a part of Volume 4 at the beginning.)
(The word 'Takamanohara' appears in "Nihon Shoki" only twice; one is this reference of the Empress Jito and the other appears in a part of Volume 4 at the beginning.)
(The word 'Takamanohara' appears in "Nihonshoki" only twice; one is this reference of the Empress Jito and the other appears in a part of Volume four at the beginning.)

sen.j: 漢風諡号、持統天皇は代々の天皇とともに淡海三船により、熟語の「継体持統」から持統と名付けられたとされる。
sen.e: The Chinese-style posthumous name, Jito, was given after a phrase 'Keitai jito'(maintenance of the imperial rule) by OMI no Mifune who gave posthumous name also to other emperors.
The Chinese-style posthumous name, Jito, was given after a phrase 'Keitai jito'(maintenance of the imperial rule) by OMI no Mifune who also gave posthumous names to other emperors.
The Chinese-style posthumous name, Jito, was given after a phrase 'Keitai jito' (maintenance of the imperial rule) by OMI no Mifune who also gave posthumous names to other emperors.

sen.j: 経歴
sen.e: Background
Background
Background

sen.j: 天智天皇の娘で、母は蘇我倉山田石川麻呂の娘、遠智娘（おちのいらつめ）。
sen.e: Her father was the Emperor Tenchi, and her mother was Ochi no iratsume, a daughter of SOGANOKURA-YAMADA no Ishikawamaro.
Her father was the Emperor Tenchi, and her mother was Ochi no iratsume, a daughter of SOGANOKURA-YAMADA no Ishikawamaro.
Her father was the Emperor Tenchi, and her mother was Ochi no Iratsume, a daughter of SOGANOKURA-YAMADA no Ishikawamaro.

sen.j: 同母姉の大田皇女とともに、父の同母弟である大海人皇子（のちの天武天皇）の妃となった。
sen.e: She married her father's younger maternal half-brother, Prince Oama (later the Emperor Tenmu), together with her older maternal half-sister, Ota no himemiko.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: She married her father's younger maternal half-brother, Prince Oama (later the Emperor Tenmu), together with her older maternal half-sister, Ota no himemiko.
She married her father's younger maternal half-brother, Oama no Miko (Prince Oama, later the Emperor Tenmu), together with her older maternal half-sister, Ota no Himemiko.

sen.j: 草壁皇子をもうけた。
sen.e: She gave birth to Prince Kusakabe.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: She gave birth to Prince Kusakabe.
She gave birth to Kusakabe no Miko (Prince Kusakabe).

sen.j: 天智天皇の晩年には、皇位継承をめぐって夫・大海人皇子と父・天智天皇の仲が悪化。
sen.e: In later years of the Emperor Tenchi, disputes over the succession to the Imperial Throne estranged her husband Prince Oama from her father the Emperor Tenchi.
In the later years of the Emperor Tenchi, disputes over the succession to the Imperial Throne estranged her husband Prince Oama from her father the Emperor Tenchi.
In the later years of the Emperor Tenchi, disputes over the succession to the Imperial Throne estranged her husband Oama no Miko from her father the Emperor Tenchi.

sen.j: 大海人皇子は東宮（皇太子）を辞し、天智の死後は大和国吉野に逃れた。
sen.e: Prince Oama abandoned his position of Togu (Crown Prince), and after the death of the Emperor Tenchi, he moved to Yoshino region in Yamato Province.
Prince Oama abandoned his position of Togu (Crown Prince), and after the death of the Emperor Tenchi, he moved to the Yoshino region in Yamato Province.
Oama no Miko abandoned his position of Togu (Crown Prince), and after the death of the Emperor Tenchi, he moved to the Yoshino region in Yamato Province.

sen.j: 持統はともに吉野へ落ち、壬申の乱まで吉野で過ごした。
sen.e: Jito went down to Yoshino with her husband, and stayed there until the Jinshin War.
Jito went down to Yoshino with her husband, and stayed there until the Jinshin War.
Jito went down to Yoshino with her husband, and stayed there until the Jinshin War.

sen.j: 持統は、のち天皇に即位してからもたびたび吉野に遊んだ。
sen.e: Even after her enthronement, Jito often visited Yoshino.
Even after her enthronement, Jito often visited Yoshino.
Even after her enthronement later, Jito often visited Yoshino.

sen.j: 夫が即位するとその皇后となった。
sen.e: On her husband's enthronement, she became the empress.
On her husband's enthronement, she became the empress.
On her husband's enthronement, she became the empress.

sen.j: 夫の没後は、姉（大田皇女）の皇子・大津皇子を謀反の嫌疑をかけて殺した。
sen.e: After her husband's death, she killed Prince Otsu, a son of her sister Ota no himemiko, suspecting him to be a rebel.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After her husband's death, she killed Prince Otsu, a son of her sister Ota no himemiko, suspecting him to be a rebel.
After her husband's death, she killed Otsu no Miko (Prince Otsu), a son of her sister Ota no Himemiko, suspecting him to be a rebel.

sen.j: 自分の息子である草壁皇子を皇太子としたが、草壁は即位する前に早世。
sen.e: She gave the investiture of the Crown Prince to her son, Prince Kusakabe, but he died young before enthronement.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: She gave the investiture of the Crown Prince to her son, Prince Kusakabe, but he died young before enthronement.
She gave the investiture of the Crown Prince to her son, Kusakabe no Miko, but he died young before enthronement.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 数年の称制を経て、自身が女帝として690年、飛鳥浄御原宮で即位した。
sen.e: After several years of shosei, she ascended the throne as an empress regnant at Asuka kiyomihara no miya Imperial residence in 690.
After several years of shosei, she ascended the throne as an empress regent at Asuka kiyomihara no miya Imperial residence in 690.
After several years of shosei, she ascended the throne as an empress regent at Asuka kiyomihara no miya Imperial residence in 690.

sen.j: （『扶桑略記』に、「皇后朝に臨んで称制し 丁亥の歳をもって元年となす 四年に至って即位し 大和國高市郡明日香淨御原宮藤原宅に都す」とある）
sen.e: (There is a description in "Fuso ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan), saying that the empress conducted shosei at the government in the year of hinotoi (which means 687 here); that she ascended the throne four years after; and that she put the capital in the Fujiwara Palace, Asuka kiyomihara no miya, Takaichi gun, Yamato Province.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処 「丁亥」字面の訳では通じないので西暦年数を補足しました。「藤原宅」定訳不明、藤原宮と解釈して the Fujiwara Palace と訳出しています。
sen.e: (There is a description in "Fuso ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan), saying that the empress conducted shosei at the government in the year of hinotoi (which means 687 here); that she ascended the throne four years after; and that she put the capital in the Fujiwara Palace, Asuka kiyomihara no miya, Takaichi gun, Yamato Province.)

(There is a description in "Fuso ryakki" [A Brief History of Japan], saying 'the empress conducted shosei at the government in the year of hinotoi [which means 687 here]; that she ascended the throne four years after; and that she put the capital in the Fujiwara Palace, Asuka kiyomihara no miya, Takaichi County, Yamato Province.)
sen.cmt: 半角にし、統一リストに合わせました。

sen.j: 天武が、生前に皇后の病気平癒を祈願して造営を始めた大和国の薬師寺を完成させた。
sen.e: She accomplished the construction of Yakushi-ji Temple in Yamato Province, which the Emperor Tenmu had started construction with a prayer to God for healing the sickness of the empress.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: She accomplished the construction of Yakushi-ji Temple in Yamato Province, which the Emperor Tenmu had started construction of with a prayer to God for healing the sickness of the empress.

She accomplished the construction of Yakushi-ji Temple in Yamato Province, which the Emperor Tenmu had started construction of with a prayer to God for healing the sickness of the empress during his life.

sen.j: これを勅願寺とした。
sen.e: She certified the temple as a chokugan-ji (temple built at the order of the emperor).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: She certified the temple as a chokugan-ji (temple built at the order of the emperor).
She certified the temple as a chokugan-ji (temple built at the order of the emperor).

sen.j: 694年には、かねてから造営していた藤原宮に遷都した。
sen.e: In 694, she transferred the capital to the Fujiwara Palace that she had been preparing.
In 694, she transferred the capital to the Fujiwara Palace that she had been preparing.
In 694, she transferred the capital to the Fujiwara Palace that she had been preparing.

sen.j: 697年、草壁皇子の遺児、文武天皇を15歳で立太子させた。
sen.e: In 697, she gave the investiture of the Crown Prince to Emperor Monmu, a posthumous child of Prince Kusakabe, at the age of 15.
In 697, she gave the investiture of the Crown Prince to Emperor Monmu, a posthumous child of Prince Kusakabe, at the age of 15.
In 697, she gave the investiture of the Crown Prince to Emperor Monmu, a posthumous child of Kusakabe no Miko, at the age of 15.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 同年譲位し、自らは天皇を後見した。
sen.e: In the same year, she abdicated the throne and started to act as a guardian of the emperor.
In the same year, she abdicated the throne and started to act as a guardian of the emperor.
In the same year, she abdicated the throne and started to act as a guardian of the emperor.

sen.j: 初めて、譲位後に太上天皇を名乗った。
sen.e: She became the first Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor/Empress) after abdication.
She became the first Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor/Empress) after abdication.
She became the first Daijo Tenno (the Retired Emperor or Empress) after abdication.

sen.j: 690年、伊勢神宮の外宮で第一回の式年遷宮を行った。
sen.e: In 690, she conducted the first shikinen sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building once in a prescribed number of years) in the Geku (the outer shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine.
In 690, she conducted the first shikinen sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building once in a prescribed number of years) in the Geku (the outer shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine.
In 690, she conducted the first shikinen sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building once in a prescribed number of years) in the Geku (the outer shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 父：天智天皇
sen.e: Father: the Emperor Tenchi
Father: the Emperor Tenchi
Father: The Emperor Tenchi

sen.j: 母：蘇我遠智娘
sen.e: Mother: SOGA no ochi no iratsume
Mother: SOGA no ochi no iratsume
Mother: SOGA no Ochi no Iratsume

sen.j: 同母姉弟：大田皇女、建皇子
sen.e: Maternal half-brother/sister: Ota no himemiko, Takeru no miko
Maternal half-brother/sister: Ota no himemiko, Takeru no miko
Younger maternal half-brother or sister: Ota no Himemiko, Takeru no Miko

sen.j: 夫：天武天皇
sen.e: Husband: the Emperor Tenmu
Husband: the Emperor Tenmu
Husband: The Emperor Tenmu

sen.j: 子：草壁皇子
sen.e: Child: Prince Kusakabe
Child: Prince Kusakabe
Child: Kusakabe no Miko
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 孫：珂瑠皇子（文武天皇）、氷高皇女（元正天皇）、吉備内親王（長屋王妃）
sen.e: Grandchildren: Karu no miko (the Emperor Monmu), Hitaka no himemiko (the Empress Gensho), Imperial Princess Kibi (empress of Nagaya no okimi)
Grandchildren: Karu no miko (the Emperor Monmu), Hitaka no himemiko (the Empress Gensho), Imperial Princess Kibi (empress of Nagaya no okimi)
Grandchildren: Karu no miko (the Emperor Monmu), Hitaka no Himemiko (the Empress Gensho), Imperial Princess Kibi (the empress of Nagaya-o [Prince Nagaya])

sen.j: 系図
sen.e: Genealogy
Genealogy
Genealogy

sen.j: 子孫
sen.e: Descendent
Descendent
Descendent

sen.j: 持統天皇の子は早世した草壁皇子１人のみであった。
sen.e: The Empress Jito had only one child: Prince Kusakabe, who died young.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Empress Jito had only one child: Prince Kusakabe, who died young.
The Empress Jito had only one child: Kusakabe no Miko, who died young.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: その系統は天武系の嫡流として奈良時代における文化・政治の担い手となった。
sen.e: Their direct descendants formed the Imperial line from the Emperor Tenmu, and played an important role in the field of culture and politics during Nara period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Their direct descendants formed the Imperial line from the Emperor Tenmu, and played an important role in the field of culture and politics during the Nara period.
Their direct descendants formed the Imperial line from the Emperor Tenmu, and played an important role in the field of culture and politics during the Nara period.

sen.j: しかしながら玄孫の孝謙天皇で天武天皇系から天智天皇系の光仁天皇に移った。
sen.e: However, her great-great grandchild, the Empress Koken, was the last empress regnant in the Imperial line from the Emperor Tenmu, and the next emperor was the Emperor Konin in the Imperial line from the Emperor Tenchi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, her great-great grandchild, the Empress Koken, was the last empress regent in the Imperial line from Emperor Tenmu, and the next emperor was Emperor Konin in the Imperial line from Emperor Tenchi.

However, her great-great grandchild, the Empress Koken, was the last empress regent in the Imperial line from Emperor Tenmu, and the next emperor was Emperor Konin in the Imperial line from Emperor Tenchi.

sen.j: そして奈良時代の終末を迎えることになった。
sen.e: On this occasion came the end of Nara period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On this occasion came the end of the Nara period.
On this occasion came the end of the Nara period.

sen.j: 光仁天皇の皇后として、称徳天皇の妹である井上内親王が立てられた。
sen.e: A younger sister of the Empress Shotoku, Imperial Princess Inoe, was chosen as the empress to the Emperor Konin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処 称徳天皇＝孝謙天皇である旨補足することも考えましたが情報の足しすぎかとも考え、追加はしていません。
sen.e: A younger sister of the Empress Shotoku, Imperial Princess Inoe, was chosen as the empress to the Emperor Konin.
A younger sister of the Empress Shotoku, Imperial Princess Inoe, was chosen as the empress to the Emperor Konin.

sen.j: 間の子である他戸親王(持統天皇の来孫)が、天智・天武皇統融合の象徴として立太子された。
sen.e: Their child, Imperial Prince Osabe (the Empress Jito's great-great-great grandchild) received the investiture of the Crown Prince as a symbol of fusion of the two Imperial lines of Tenchi and Tenmu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Their child, Imperial Prince Osabe (the Empress Jito's great-great-great grandchild) received the investiture of the Crown Prince as a symbol of fusion of the two Imperial lines of Tenchi and Tenmu.
Their child, Imperial Prince Osabe (the Empress Jito's great-great-great grandchild) received the investiture of the Crown Prince as a symbol of fusion of the two Imperial lines of Tenchi and Tenmu.

sen.j: しかしながら謀反の罪に問われ庶人に落とされた後、母共々変死した。
sen.e: However, Imperial Prince Osabe was suspected to be a rebel, was forced to demote from nobility to subject, and finally died an unnatural death together with his mother.
However, Imperial Prince Osabe was suspected to be a rebel, was forced to demote from nobility to subject, and finally died an unnatural death together with his mother.
However, he was suspected to be a rebel, forced to demote from nobility to subject, and finally died an unnatural death together with his mother.

sen.j: 他戸親王の姉の酒人内親王は桓武天皇の妃となり、朝原内親王(平城天皇の妃)を儲けた。
sen.e: An older sister of Imperial Prince Osabe, Imperial Princess Sakahito got married to the Emperor Kanmu, and gave birth to Imperial Princess Asahara, who got married to the Emperor Heizei.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: An older sister of Imperial Prince Osabe, Imperial Princess Sakahito got married to the Emperor Kanmu, and gave birth to Imperial Princess Asahara, who got married to the Emperor Heizei.
An older sister of Imperial Prince Osabe, Imperial Princess Sakahito got married to the Emperor Kanmu, and gave birth to Imperial Princess Asahara, who got married to the Emperor Heizei.

sen.j: だが、彼女は子を成さなかった。
sen.e: But Asahara had no children.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: But Asahara had no children.
But Asahara had no children.

sen.j: 臣籍降下した中では承和 (日本)11年（844年）に昆孫の峯緒王が高階真人姓を賜り高階氏の祖となった。
sen.e: Among the Empress Jito's descendents who demoted from nobility to subject, her great-great-great-great grandchild Prince Mineo received the name of TAKASHINA no Mahito in 844, and became an ancestor of the Takashina clan.

Among the Empress Jito's descendents who demoted from nobility to subject, her great-great-great-great grandchild Prince Mineo received the name of TAKASHINA no Mahito in 844, and became an ancestor of the Takashina clan.

Among the Empress Jito's descendents who demoted from nobility to subject, her great-great-great-great grandchild Mineo no Miko (Prince Mineo) received the surname of TAKASHINA no Mahito in 844, and became an ancestor of the Takashina clan.

sen.j: しかしながら子の高階茂範(持統天皇の仍孫)は養子を取り家督を継がせているため、彼を最後に持統天皇の系統は断絶することになった。
sen.e: However, his child, Shigenori TAKASHINA (the Empress Jito's great-great-great-great-great grandchild) had the position of family head succeeded to his adopted child, so the Imperial line of the Empress Jito ended at this generation.

However, his child, Shigenori TAKASHINA (the Empress Jito's great-great-great-great-great grandchild) had the position of family head succeeded to his adopted child, so the Imperial line of the Empress Jito ended at this generation.

However, his child, Shigenori TAKASHINA (the Empress Jito's great-great-great-great-great grandchild) had the position of family head succeeded to his adopted child, so the Imperial line of the Empress Jito ended at his generation.

sen.j: 但し皇子の身分を剥奪された曾孫の広成皇子・広世皇子両皇子など、歴史の闇の彼方へ姿を消すものもある。
sen.e: The Empress Jito had great grandchildren, including Prince Hironari and Prince Hiroyo, but they had to demote to subject and so their descendents are unknown.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Empress Jito had great grandchildren, including Prince Hironari and Prince Hiroyo, but they had to demote to subject and so their descendents are unknown.
The Empress Jito had great grandchildren, including Hironari no Miko (Prince Hironari) and Hiroyo no Miko (Prince Hiroyo), who had to demote to subject, so their descendents are unknown.

sen.j: 彼らを通じ現在でも子孫がいると思われる。
sen.e: The Empress Jito's direct descendants from those two great grandchildren might exist at present.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Empress Jito's direct descendants from those two great grandchildren might exist at present.
The Empress Jito's direct descendants from those two great grandchildren might exist at present.

sen.j: 万葉歌人
sen.e: Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) Poet
Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) Poet
Manyoshu (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves) Poet

sen.j: 万葉歌人としても万葉集巻1雑歌28に藤原宮御宇天皇代（高天原廣野姫天皇 元年丁亥11年譲位軽太子尊号曰太上天皇）天皇御製歌として名を留めている。
sen.e: Her tanka-poem appears in Manyoshu volume 1 as the 28th zouka (poems other than love poems and elegies), and her name is referred to as the Empress at Fujiwara Palace, Takamanohara hiro no hime no sumeramikoto who started ruling on the year of hinotoi, abdicated the throne to Karu no hitsugi no miko on the 11th year and became a Daijo Tenno.

Her tanka-poem appears in Manyoshu volume 1 as the 28th zouka (poems other than love poems and elegies), and her name is referred to as the Empress at Fujiwara Palace, Takamanohara hiro no hime no sumeramikoto who started ruling on the year of hinotoi, abdicated the throne to Karu no hitsugi no miko on the 11th year and became a Daijo Tenno.

Her tanka (31 syllables' poem) appears in Manyoshu volume one as the 28th zoka (poems other than love poems and elegies), and her name is referred to as the Empress at Fujiwara Palace (Takamanohara Hirono Hime no Sumeramikoto; who started ruling in 686 for 11 years, abdicated the throne to Karu no Hitsugi no miko [Emperor Monmu] and became a Daijo Tenno [the retired empress]).
sen.cmt: 表記を変え、用語補足しました。

sen.j: 「春過而 夏來良之 白妙能 衣乾有 天之香來山」
sen.e: 春過而 夏來良之 白妙能 衣乾有 天之香來山'
sen.cmt: この歌が何通りかに読み下される説明が続き、またそのうち意味の違うものもあるので、ここで音訳や意味の訳出をしても無意味と考え、漢字のままとしています。
sen.e: 春過而 夏來良之 白妙能 衣乾有 天之香來山'
春過而 夏來良之 白妙能 衣乾有 天之香來山'

sen.j: 春過ぎて 夏来るらし 白妙の 衣干したり 天香具山（定訓）
sen.e: The above poem written in Chinese style is generally translated into Japanese like this: Harusugite natsu kitarurashi shirotae no koromo hoshitari Amanokagu-yama (It seems that spring is over and summer has come, as white robes are spread to dry on Mt. Amanokagu)
sen.cmt: この読み下しは、次の段のものと意味が変わらない（読み方が違うことが重要）なので、音訳を先に出し、意味の訳出をつけました。
sen.e: The above poem written in Chinese style is generally translated into Japanese like this: Harusugite natsu kitarurashi shirotae no koromo hoshitari Amanokagu-yama (It seems that spring is over and summer has come, as white robes are spread to dry on Mt. Amanokagu)

The above poem written in Chinese style is generally translated into Japanese like this: Harusugite natsu kitarurashi shirotae no koromo hoshitari Amanokagu-yama (It seems that spring is over and summer has come, as white robes are spread to dry on Mt. Amanokagu).
sen.cmt: ピリオドを補足しました。

sen.j: 春過ぎて夏ぞ來ぬらし白妙の衣かはかすあまのかぐ山（古来風躰抄）
sen.e: In "Korai futeisho" (Poetic Styles from the Past), it is translated like this: Harusugite natsu zo kinurashi shirotae no koromo kawakasu Amanokagu-yama (meaning is the same)
sen.cmt: 形式は上段に従いました。
sen.e: In "Korai futeisho" (Poetic Styles from the Past), it is translated like this: Harusugite natsu zo kinurashi shirotae no koromo kawakasu Amanokagu-yama (meaning is the same)
In Korai futeisho (Poetic Styles from the Past), it is translated like this: Harusugite natsu zo kinurashi shirotae no koromo kawakasu Amanokagu-yama (meaning is the same)

sen.j: この歌は小倉百人一首にも選ばれている。
sen.e: This poem also appears in Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (The Ogura Anthology of One Hundred Tanka-poems by One Hundred Poets).
This poem also appears in Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (The Ogura Anthology of One Hundred Tanka-poems by One Hundred Poets).
This poem also appears in Ogura Hyakunin Isshu (The Ogura Anthology of 100 Tanka poems by 100 Poets).

sen.j: 「春すぎて夏來にけらし白妙の 衣ほすてふ天の香具山」小倉百人一首
sen.e: In Ogura Hyakunin Isshu, it is translated like this: Harusugite natsu kinikerashi shirotae no koromo hosucho Amanokagu-yama (It seems that spring is over and summer has come, for the white robes, so it is said, are spread to dry on Mt. Amanokagu)

In Ogura Hyakunin Isshu, it is translated like this: Harusugite natsu kinikerashi shirotae no koromo hosucho Amanokagu-yama (It seems that spring is over and summer has come, for the white robes, so it is said, are spread to dry on Mt. Amanokagu)

In Ogura Hyakunin Isshu, it is translated like this: Harusugite natsu kinikerashi shirotae no koromo hosucho Amanokagu-yama (It seems that spring is over and summer has come, for the white robes, so it is said, are spread to dry on Mt. Amanokagu).
sen.cmt: ピリオドを補足しました。

sen.j: 陵
sen.e: Mausoleum
Mausoleum
Mausoleum

sen.j: 陵は檜隈大内陵（奈良県高市郡明日香村大字野口）、野口王墓。
sen.e: Her mausoleum is Noguchino Ono-haka Tumulus in Hinokuma Ouchi no Misasagi Mausoleum, located at Oaza Noguchi, Asuka-mura, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
Her mausoleum is Noguchino Ono-haka Tumulus in Hinokuma Ouchi no Misasagi Mausoleum, located at Oaza Noguchi, Asuka-mura, Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
Her mausoleum is Noguchio no Haka Tumulus in Hinokuma Ouchi no Misasagi Mausoleum (Oaza Noguchi, Asuka-mura, Takaichi County, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 夫天武天皇との夫婦合葬墓である。
sen.e: This is a joint mausoleum of the Empress Jito and her husband, the Emperor Tenmu.
This is a joint mausoleum of the Empress Jito and her husband, the Emperor Tenmu.
This is a joint mausoleum of the Empress Jito and her husband, the Emperor Tenmu.

sen.j: 大化2年に出された古墳薄葬令により天皇としては初めて火葬された。
sen.e: She was the first emperor/empress to be cremated according to Kofun hakuso rei (Simple Burial Act), which came into effect in 646.
She was the first emperor/empress to be cremated according to Kofun hakuso rei (Simple Burial Act), which came into effect in 646.
She was the first imperial ruler to be cremated according to Kofun hakuso rei (Simple Burial Act), which came into effect in 646.

sen.j: この陵は古代の天皇陵としては珍しく、治定に間違いがないとされる。
sen.e: This mausoleum is identified as that of the Empress Jito with quite a high certainty, which is not a usual case with other ancient imperial mausoleums.
This mausoleum is identified as that of the Empress Jito with quite a high certainty, which is not the usual case with other ancient imperial mausoleums.
This mausoleum is identified as that of the Empress Jito with quite a high certainty, which is not the usual case with other ancient imperial mausoleums.

sen.j: 天武天皇とともに合葬され、持統天皇の遺骨は銀の骨壺に収められていた。
sen.e: She was buried with her husband the Emperor Tenmu, and her ashes were kept in a silver urn.
She was buried with her husband the Emperor Tenmu, and her ashes were kept in a silver urn.
She was buried with her husband the Emperor Tenmu, and her ashes were kept in a silver urn.

sen.j: しかし、1235年（文暦2）に盗掘にあった。
sen.e: However, the mausoleum was robbed in 1235.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, the mausoleum was robbed in 1235.
However, the mausoleum was robbed in 1235.

sen.j: その際に骨壺だけ奪い去られて遺骨は近くに遺棄されたという。
sen.e: The urn was gone and the ashes were thrown away somewhere around the mausoleum.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The urn was gone and the ashes were thrown away somewhere around the mausoleum.
The urn was gone and the ashes were thrown away somewhere around the mausoleum.

sen.j: 藤原定家の『明月記』に盗掘の顛末が記されている。
sen.e: "Meigetsuki diary" by FUJIWARA no Teika describes the whole story of the robbery.
"Meigetsuki diary" by FUJIWARA no Teika describes the whole story of the robbery.
"Meigetsuki diary" by FUJIWARA no Teika describes the whole story of the robbery.

sen.j: また、盗掘の際に作成された『阿不幾乃山陵記』に石室の様子が書かれている。
sen.e: And the investigation report of the robbery, "Afuki no sanryoki," describes the space inside the mausoleum.
And the investigation report of the robbery, "Afuki no sanryoki," describes the space inside the mausoleum.
And the investigation report of the robbery, "Afuki no sanryoki," describes its rock chamber.
sen.cmt: 半角に用語を変えました。

tit.j: 在位年と西暦との対照表
tit.e: Chronological table of her reigning period shown in A.D.
Chronological table of her reigning period shown in A.D.
Comparative chart of the years of his reign and the Christian years
